Flames start with some sort of fuel like in the wick of a candle and rapidly react with the oxygen in the air after some activation energy is introduced, aka heat. The oxygen atoms rapidly remove the electrons in the fuel’s atoms. As a result of this reaction, energy is released and is absorbed by the products and reactants and converted into their temperature. Light is then emitted and received by our eyes as the image of a flame. The flame itself has high temperatures and the light transfers enough energy to our skin to warm our skin up. The flame itself is made of the products and reactants, including fuel, an oxidizer, water, and carbon dioxide, and also ions as shown in the video.

this happens with high voltage utility systems and it is very common. In overhead high voltage electrical distribution systems when branches fall into them, or components fail, there are fires all the time. Flames are conductive from these fires and can cause continuous arcing between the phases when there is a flame between the phases, or betwen the phases and ground. The flame reduces the clearance distance between the phases as the flame is literally conductive. The arc jumps because the air becomes  ionized, since the distance has been shortened by a conductive presence within the distances that normally allow free air to be the insulator or dielectric,  and it is attracted to the closest point of conduction, which is the least path of resistance to the opposite phase or ground. Since the candle's flame is conductive, since there is a lot of carbon emitted from the flame, the creepage distance is being shortened closer than it's normal clearance distance and the high voltage forms a corona discharge, ionizing the air, and it jumps to the conductive flame, then it continues it's path through what is now ionized on the other side of the flame to the oppositely charged  conductor, completing the shortest path as a return to either an opposite phase or ground. In phase to phase faults,  there is always more of an attraction because there is a greater difference in potential. Phase to ground is always a lower voltage because when there is a grounded neutral, it always comes from a center tap of a transformer where the voltage is split in half,.With high voltages, since they ionize the air, they jump with great force, and, the proof is there, the flame causes conduction.  Not all fire is conductive, it all matters how much carbon is left over and in the flame from the compounds that are set on fire, since fire separates the compounds and breaks them down into their key elements, or transforms the compounds into other compounds, releasing carbons while they work, kind of the same thing acids do, except they work to transform without ignition. If you burn a candle, wax has large quantities of carbon left over that carry into a flame. Carbon is one of the most conductive elements on the planet and is the base element of all organic compounds. This is why the candle flame leaves a soot residue when put close to objects such as white ceilings, etc. If we have a flame from clean alcohol, the majority of the carbon is gone from the burn process and the flame is blue. The flame most likely is already of a close to pure plasma state, however, fire does contain plasma but isn't a plasma per se. It is fire.. Ionized molecules are energized and therefore conductive. Fire can be conductive, but again more experimentation is needed to say all flames are conductive,. I would imagine that all organic compounds that are burnt will create a carbon flame and it should be orange, as well conductive. Add more oxygen and this can all change, leaning the emission away from the flame causing a cleaner burn and less conductivity. Carbons can be compounded together to also create insulators, such as rubber, however, if we burn rubber, the flame from the rubber is highly conductive because of the very high carbon emissions and nasty smokey flame. So, we could get both conductive and non conductive flames.. I believe all conductiong flamesare based upon carbon content if the arc jumps to them.

I took my plasma lamp and wrapped it in aluminum foil and then I created a conductive platform out of cardboard and aluminum foil. I then set the conductive platform, (I called it a shock table), so that it was touching the plasma lamp with a large surface area. I then would take a paper clip, and I would jump a shock a centimeter between the table and the paper clip. I would spray flammable substances on the shock table, and then light it on fire with shocks, and the shock could change the shape of the flame. This is how I discovered this on my own.

Actually, I suspect that the smoke does not contain ions. Obviously, the flame does. The smoke gets polarised and attracted by the inhomogenous electric field. It's an explanation for someone who may not have a background in chemistry. You're technically right, but also maybe overwhelming. Besides, NaCl is a simple case, but you don't have hydroxide atoms or fluorosilicate atoms and who calls them molecules? Though when dissolved in solution, they may recombine with different ions of an appropriate charge level. I think calling them molecules confuses what they are and implies stability, but a molecule will often dissociate into two ions.

Ions aren't really "half molecules": it's better to think of them as atoms or molecules with the wrong number of electrons. For example, there's no such thing as a "sodium chloride molecule" so sodium and chloride ions can't be half of that non-existent molecule. Rather, a chloride ion is a chlorine atom that has gained an electron. It now has more electrons than protons, so it's negatively charged; it's stable because the extra electron fills up a shell.

The smoke isn't "candle". It's partially burnt bits of wax or, if you prefer, bits of wax that have been decomposed by being heated -- just after the flame has gone out, the wick is still hot and that heat continues to break down the wax molecules. At 2:00, you can see the smoke splits in three: positive ions go one way, negative ions the other way, and uncharged particles go upwards.

Hard to say exactly - fire is a phenomenon, and ions are material, but most of the time they can be thought of as "half molecules," so the ions in the flame are the heated candle, but when they're not burning, they're just molecules, not ions.
And yet every time I look up "Is fire a plasma?" an overwhelming number of people say "No"

The energy source is important in your examples.  Your wall outlet is driven by the city power grid, which delivers relatively high current (15amps for most US households) with low voltage.  A Taser is driven by a battery (typically 9v, 500mAh from a quick Google).  In order for the Taser to get up to 20k-50k volts, the current is driven way down (about 2mAh), trading current for voltage.  And that's what Ohm's Law really shows -- the equivalency of the three properties.

'Volts don't kill, Amps do' is a little oversimplified. Ohm's law stays valid. Body resistance is 1kΩ - 100kΩ, so at 20kV, that's 0,2A to 20A. Energy dissipation (V * I): 4kW - 400kW (!!). If you connect yourself to 20kV for just a second, you heat up like a toaster.

What really happens when touching these kinds of 'safe' high-voltage devices, is the voltage drops to zero almost instantaneously when you touch it, and it ramps up the voltage again after a few milliseconds, continuing in a cycle.

It's really joules that kill you, or, more correctly, watts, or joules per second. Or is it coulombs? A high voltage, low coulomb source, like a Van DeGraf, will cause a very high current to flow, but only for a few nanoseconds. This will cause local pain, and cause nearby muscles to twitch, but it will dissipate long before it has a chance to disrupt your heart's rhythms, and is far to little energy to overheat and damage muscle. 
Volts, amps and time all have a role.

The high resistance of the air causes much of the energy of the electrons jumping the distance to be dissipated as intense, but brief heat, causing the air along the path it passes through to expand very rapidly, but only for a moment. The resultant pressure wave front is what we hear.

I’m guessing this was powered off a wall outlet via a transformer. Presuming that and, say, a 20A fuse, the max current would be 120mA at most, for safety’s sake. As far as why he didn’t blow out the fuse, I’d attribute that to the fact that he didn’t touch the plates directly. As he indicated, air is a very poor conductor, thus the space of air between his hand and the plate adds a significant amount of resistance to satisfy your Ohm’s law problem. Besides, we’re pretty terrible conductors too.
